title: Niederalben
text:
Niederalben is an "<a href="Ortsgemeinde">Ortsgemeinde</a>" – a <a href="Municipalities%20of%20Germany">municipality</a> belonging to a "<a href="Verbandsgemeinde">Verbandsgemeinde</a>", a kind of collective municipality – in the <a href="Kusel%20%28district%29">Kusel</a> <a href="Districts%20of%20Germany">district</a> in <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. It belongs to the <a href="Kusel-Altenglan">"Verbandsgemeinde" of Kusel-Altenglan</a>, whose seat is in <a href="Kusel">Kusel</a>.
Geography.
Location.
The municipality lies in the Steinalb valley in the Western <a href="Palatinate%20%28region%29">Palatinate</a>. The municipal area is 72.7% wooded. Niederalben lies at an elevation of between 180 and 250 m above <a href="sea%20level">sea level</a> on the Steinalb's left bank. This brook empties into the <a href="Glan%20%28Nahe%29">Glan</a> only a few hundred metres downstream from the village. Running alongside the brook is a village <a href="bypass%20%28road%29">bypass</a>. The streets within the village itself sprout off the original through road that the bypass has now replaced and lead into the little side dales. Elevations outside the village reach heights of greater than 400 m above sea level. Among the more noteworthy of these is the Mittagsfels, with its craggy steep slopes looming over the built-up area. The Glan and Steinalb valleys are rather narrow, and on either side, a broad plateau spreads out. Two thirds of the former municipal area (before 1938) today lies within the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground, a military facility created by the <a href="Nazi%20Party">Nazis</a>.
Neighbouring municipalities.
Niederalben borders in the north on the <a href="Baumholder">Baumholder</a> Troop Drilling Ground, in the east on the municipality of <a href="Sankt%20Julian">Sankt Julian</a>, in the south on the municipality of <a href="Ulmet%2C%20Germany">Ulmet</a> and in the west on the municipality of <a href="Rathsweiler">Rathsweiler</a>.
Constituent communities.
Also belonging to Niederalben is the outlying homestead of Neuwirtshaus.
Municipality’s layout.
Niederalben's appearance is characterized by its topographical location. The street with the newer houses runs parallel to the Steinalb, right near which building was formerly avoided owing to the <a href="flood">flood</a>ing danger. In the narrow side dales, two centres have formed, called "Oberdorf" and "Unterdorf" ("upper village" and "lower village"). Where the two side dales meet stands the old village <a href="church%20%28building%29">church</a>. Nearby stands the <a href="Evangelical%20Church%20in%20Germany">Evangelical</a> parish hall, which long served as a stand-in church, although the old church has now been properly renovated and now once more fulfils its original purpose. The trend towards "modernity" claimed many old farmhouses in the rush to convert existing properties, often radically, into modern dwellings, but nowadays the trend is more towards striving to preserve older building forms. The municipality has become almost wholly a residential community, a great shift from its former function as a pure farming village. In 1994, the <a href="Phenology">phenological</a> <a href="weather%20station">weather station</a> run by the <a href="Deutscher%20Wetterdienst">German Weather Service</a> in <a href="Offenbach-Hundheim">Offenbach</a> was closed after having existed since the end of the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, the municipality had a vast woodland in the Steinalb area that was tended by the municipality's own forester. This forest, along with a great part of the old municipal area, now belongs to the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground, a big restricted area, and is now tended by the state forest administration in <a href="Baumholder">Baumholder</a>. A forester's house for the Steinalb area long stood in Niederalben, but this has since been sold. The main farming lands are found on the high plateau on either side of the dale. The greater part of the municipal woodland now found in what is left of the municipal area was planted after the Second World War. Within the municipal area lie two nature conservation areas, "Mittagsfels" with its dry grassland and rare flora, and "Steinalbmündung", a bird conservation area.
History.
Antiquity.
<a href="Prehistory">Prehistoric</a> <a href="Archaeology">archaeological</a> finds within Niederalben's current limits are not directly established. Right at the municipal limit, however, in the cadastral area known as Schwarzland, now inside the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground, two urn graves were unearthed in 1938 from <a href="La%20T%C3%A8ne%20culture">La Tène times</a> (about 500 BC). The urns along with <a href="grave%20goods">grave goods</a> were handed over to the monument office in <a href="Trier">Trier</a> that was then responsible for such things. Prehistoric <a href="hammerstone">hammerstone</a>s have been found in within Niederalben's limits. The broader area around the village, too, is quite rich in prehistoric finds from the <a href="Middle%20Stone%20Age">Middle</a> and <a href="New%20Stone%20Age">New Stone Age</a>. Already in prehistoric times, there were linking trails over the heights leading towards <a href="Trier">Trier</a>, and later, a <a href="Roman%20roads">Roman road</a> ran through what is now the municipal area. Finds from <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Roman</a> times have not turned up in Niederalben. It is likely that the area originally lay in the Lautern royal forest, but did not belong to the lands that <a href="Franks">Frankish</a> kings donated to ecclesiastical lordships such as the <a href="Bishopric%20of%20Verdun">Bishopric of Verdun</a> or the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Reims">Bishopric of Reims</a>.
Middle Ages.
In 1287, Hunhausen (see <a href="%23Vanished%20villages">Vanished villages</a> below) had its first documentary mention. About 1290, a document mentioned a man named Wilmar Vilemann von Alben, who may well have been the first in a line of lesser noblemen of the house of Alben, who in the <a href="Late%20Middle%20Ages">Late Middle Ages</a> held important offices under <a href="Sigismund%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Emperor Sigismund</a> in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a> and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Hungary%20%281000%E2%80%931538%29">Hungary</a>. His significance is that his noble house, "Alben", bears the same name as the village, although the latter also bears the prefix "Nieder—" ("Nether" or "Lower"). Johann von <a href="Zagreb">Agram</a> from the German noble family of Alben became Chancellor of <a href="P%C3%A9cs">Fünfkirchen</a>, and his brother became Bishop of Fünfkirchen. One of the first written records about the area is a "Weistum" (a "Weistum" – <a href="cognate">cognate</a> with <a href="English%20language">English</a> "wisdom" – was a legal pronouncement issued by men learned in law in the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> and early modern times) from the "Hochgericht auf der Heide" ("<a href="Blood%20court">High Court</a> on the <a href="Heath">Heath</a>") to which a letter of enfeoffment refers as early as 1351. The High Court on the Heath – a geographical area as well as an actual court – was the land between the Steinalb, the <a href="Glan%20%28Nahe%29">Glan</a> and the <a href="Nahe%20%28Rhine%29">Nahe</a>, which in the late 10th century became more heavily settled, as witnessed in documents from both <a href="Otto%20III%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Emperor Otto III</a> and <a href="Willigis">Archbishop Willigis</a> of <a href="Electorate%20of%20Mainz">Mainz</a>. It is likely that the area later passed to the <a href="Electorate%20of%20the%20Palatinate">Electorate of the Palatinate</a> as an <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Imperial</a> pledge, and was then transferred by that state to the <a href="Waldgrave">Waldgrave</a>s and Rhinegraves of Steinkallenfels and Grumbach, along with the high court jurisdiction. Already by <a href="Ottonian%20dynasty">Ottonian</a> times, the area was no longer held by the kingly treasury anyway. In a directory of <a href="fief">fief</a>s from about 1200 for the Rhinegrave Wolfram, it says: "Item de Abbate de Sancto Albano habet Ringravius in feodo Helbach und Wiselbach apud Winterhuche, duas villas cum omni iure." This text in somewhat fractured <a href="Mediaeval%20Latin">Mediaeval Latin</a> – it even has the <a href="German%20language">German</a> word "und" thrown in in one place – roughly translates as "Likewise from <a href="St.%20Alban%27s%20Abbey%2C%20Mainz">Saint Alban’s Abbey</a>, the Rhinegrave has in fief "Helbach" and "Wiselbach" near "Winterhuche", two estates with all rights." The high court jurisdiction in the region of the High Court on the Heath was never challenged. In 1429, the Waldgraves and Rhinegraves enfeoffed a man named Johann von Hagen with the villages and courts of "Alben", "Nyderalben" and "Hunehausen". Here, the name "Alben" was used for a place that still exists now, part of Niederalben, and today customarily called the "Oberdorf" ("upper village").
Modern times.
In the 16th century, Niederalben – here meaning only the part today customarily called the "Unterdorf" ("lower village") – passed to the Lords of Groroth. The Lords of Hagen owned 18 house-based persons while the Lords of Groroth owned eight or nine in what were then the two villages. In 1650, the rights held by the Lords of Groroth passed back to the Rhinegraves. In 1791, the last Lord of Hagen died, and thus Niederalben likewise passed back to the Rhinegraves.
Recent times.
During the time of the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a> and the <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>ic era that followed, the German lands on the <a href="Rhine">Rhine</a>’s left bank were annexed by France. Niederalben found itself within the French state in 1801. With the new political arrangement and within the new boundaries, Niederalben found itself in the <a href="Cantons%20of%20France">Canton</a> of Grumbach, the <a href="Arrondissements%20of%20France">Arrondissement</a> of Birkenfeld and the <a href="Departments%20of%20France">Department</a> of <a href="Sarre%20%28department%29">Sarre</a>. After <a href="France">French</a> rule, the <a href="Congress%20of%20Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> drew new boundaries yet again. In 1816, Niederalben passed to the <a href="Principality%20of%20Lichtenberg">Principality of Lichtenberg</a>, a newly created <a href="exclave">exclave</a> of the Duchy of <a href="Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld">Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld</a>, which in 1826 became the Duchy of <a href="Saxe-Coburg%20and%20Gotha">Saxe-Coburg and Gotha</a>. As part of this state, it passed in 1834 by sale to the Kingdom of <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a>, which made this area into the Sankt Wendel district. Later, after the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a> stipulated, among other things, that 26 of the Sankt Wendel district’s 94 municipalities had to be ceded to the <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a>- and <a href="France">French</a>-<a href="Military%20occupation">occupied</a> <a href="Saar%20%28League%20of%20Nations%29">Saar</a>. The remaining 68 municipalities then bore the designation "Restkreis St. Wendel-Baumholder", with the first syllable of "Restkreis" having the same meaning as in English, in the sense of "left over". Niederalben belonged to this district until 1937, when it was transferred to the <a href="Birkenfeld%20%28district%29">Birkenfeld district</a>, which had formerly been under <a href="Free%20State%20of%20Oldenburg">Oldenburg</a> administration. After <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a>’s downfall and Germany's defeat in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, the municipality was grouped into the then newly founded (1946) <a href="States%20of%20Germany">state</a> of <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a>, all the while still in the Birkenfeld district, but now also in the "<a href="Regierungsbezirk">Regierungsbezirk</a>" of Koblenz. In the course of administrative restructuring in the state, Niederalben passed to the "Regierungsbezirk" of <a href="Rheinhessen-Pfalz">Rheinhessen-Pfalz</a>, and in 1969, it was transferred, this time to the Kusel district, in which it remains today. In 1972, Niederalben was grouped as an "<a href="Ortsgemeinde">Ortsgemeinde</a>" into the <a href="Altenglan%20%28Verbandsgemeinde%29">"Verbandsgemeinde" of Altenglan</a>. In 1974, the village <a href="bypass%20%28road%29">bypass</a> was built.
Population development.
In 1429, twenty-seven house-based persons were counted in what is now Niederalben. Going by this figure, the total population was some 200 inhabitants. In the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a> and <a href="France">French</a> <a href="Louis%20XIV%20of%20France">King Louis XIV's</a> wars of conquest, there was great loss of life. Nevertheless, by the 18th century the population had grown roughly threefold over what it had been in the 15th, first with new settlers after the war and then strong growth. This made many inhabitants in the 19th century choose <a href="emigration">emigration</a>. In 1833, there were 526 persons living in Niederalben in 87 families. Among the adults were 131 men and 161 women, while among the children were 161 boys and 103 girls. Seven people lived outside the village. By religion, 449 inhabitants were <a href="Evangelical%20Church%20in%20Germany">Evangelical</a> and 70 <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a>. There were no <a href="Judaism">Jews</a>, nor were there any <a href="Mennonite">Mennonite</a>s. In the late 19th century and in the earlier half of the 20th, the population had evened off to a level of 500 inhabitants. Between 1945 and 1950 came a noticeable upswing from 520 to 575 inhabitants, brought about by <a href="Flight%20and%20expulsion%20of%20Germans%20from%20Poland%20during%20and%20after%20World%20War%20II">ethnic Germans driven out of Germany's former eastern territories</a> and <a href="Republikflucht">people who had fled East Germany</a> arriving in Niederalben. Between 1950 and 1960, the population grew at first only slowly, and then abruptly dropped off to about 500. Many of those who had been forced to come here left again seeking places with better industrial structure. Even young people had no job opportunities. In 1996, the village had only 400 inhabitants, of whom almost a fourth were over 60 years of age. Also counted in that total are <a href="Political%20asylum">asylum</a> seekers with many children. By 2007, the population had further fallen to 343. Many people in the last century were employed on the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground, but it must be borne in mind that this is being dissolved bit by bit. Thus, the population might yet further shrink. For decades now, young people have had to seek their livelihoods elsewhere, in other regions.

Municipality’s name.
The placename is geographical in origin, and has to do with the village lying on the brook. According to many interpretations, the name "Alb" comes from the pre-Germanic name for a body of water, "Alba". According to another theory, the name goes back to the customary Allemanic word for a brook, "Alb". In contrast to Niederalben, which lies on the Steinalb, <a href="Oberalben">Oberalben</a> lies up in the headwaters of another brook named Alb, namely the Kuralb. Since the name "Alben" is commonly encountered in the surrounding area, it can be difficult to reckon which is which in old documents. According to researchers Dolch and Greule, Niederalben had its first documentary mention in 1290.
Vanished villages.
The villages of Ohlscheid and Hunhausen have not been mentioned in documents since the late 16th century, and their municipal areas were long ago absorbed into Niederalben's. Many rural cadastral toponyms still recall these two villages, which once, like Niederalben, belonged to the "Vierherrengericht" ("Four-Lord Court") of <a href="Sankt%20Julian">Sankt Julian</a> and also to the "Hochgericht auf der Heide" ("<a href="Blood%20court">High Court</a> on the <a href="Heath">Heath</a>"). Ohlscheid lay on the ridge between Niederalben and Sankt Julian. Hunhausen, also called Hanhausen, might have been the seat of a "Hun" or "Hund". The term refers to the function borne by a lower administrative official. This village likely lay on the <a href="Glan%20%28Nahe%29">Glan's</a> not very steep left bank between Niederalben and Eschenau (one of Sankt Julian's constituent communities).
Religion.
Niederalben's old village <a href="church%20%28building%29">church</a> comes from the 14th century and, according to some stories at least, was once "Ulfilaskapelle" ("<a href="Ulfilas">Ulfilas</a>’s <a href="Chapel">Chapel</a>"). In 1588, though, Johannes Hofmann mentioned a chapel called "Sankt Wolfgang" to which "great pilgrimage from faraway foreign lands took place". This church might not have been exactly the same one as today's village church, and <a href="Wolfgang%20of%20Regensburg">Saint Wolfgang's</a> patronage may actually have applied to a now long vanished <a href="pilgrimage">pilgrimage</a> church that stood on a slope in the village's south end and that may have been destroyed in a <a href="landslide">landslide</a>. According to Hofmann's description, it stood "forward on the Steinalb, right on the way that goes from <a href="Ulmet%2C%20Germany">Ulmet</a> towards <a href="Meisenheim">Meisenheim</a>." This meant the ancient road link running from <a href="Rathsweiler">Rathsweiler</a>, by the former federal forestry office and on to Eschenau (an outlying centre of <a href="Sankt%20Julian">Sankt Julian</a>). During renovations at the still preserved village church, an expert opinion yielded a date of 1347 (give or take 8 years) for the felling of the timbers used for the roof. It is to be assumed that Niederalben was from the beginning a branch of the parish of Sankt Julian. In 1556, the Counts of Grumbach introduced <a href="Lutheranism">Lutheran</a> belief. The nave was destroyed during the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a>. For a long time, there were no services at the church, and <a href="Protestantism">Protestants</a> had to attend church services in neighbouring Sankt Julian. In 1772, the nave was renovated in <a href="Baroque%20architecture">Late Baroque</a> style, and then there could once more be church services in the village. In 1816 came a new arrangement, for Sankt Julian had become, under the <a href="Congress%20of%20Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bavaria">Bavarian</a>. The <a href="Evangelical%20Church%20in%20Germany">Evangelical</a> believers at first attended services at the Church of <a href="Offenbach-Hundheim">Offenbach am Glan</a>. In 1839, a parish of Niederalben-Erzweiler was founded, which "<a href="de%20jure">de jure</a>" still exists today. The other place that belonged to the parish, Erzweiler, which lay within the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground, was permanently dissolved about 1970 (after not having existed anyway for well over three decades). For a while beginning in 1970, there was joint parochial leadership by the pastors from Offenbach, <a href="Herren-Sulzbach">Herren-Sulzbach</a> and <a href="Medard">Medard</a>. Since 1991, the two ecclesiastical communities of Medard and Niederalben, which lie 15 km away from each other, are both tended by the pastor from Medard. The few <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a> villagers belong to the church community of <a href="Rammelsbach">Rammelsbach</a> and attend <a href="Mass%20%28liturgy%29">Mass</a> at the Catholic church in Ulmet. Formerly, there was a <a href="simultaneum">simultaneum</a> at the village's Evangelical church, but the Catholics seldom ever made use of it. The village's Catholics take part in Evangelical community life. At the old graveyard around the church, the dead of both denominations were buried. In the time of <a href="France">French</a> rule, this graveyard was <a href="Secularization">secularized</a> and ownership was transferred to the municipality. From 1835, there were no further burials at the graveyard around the church. The land was given back to the church in 1836, a deed acknowledged in an 1895 agreement. The municipal graveyard beneath the Mittagsfels was laid out in 1835.
Politics.
Municipal council.
The council is made up of 8 council members, who were elected by <a href="Plurality%20voting%20system">majority vote</a> at the municipal election held on 7 June 2009, and the honorary mayor as chairman.
Mayor.
Niederalben's mayor is Michael Rihlmann.
Coat of arms.
The municipality's <a href="Coat%20of%20arms">arms</a> might be described thus: Per bend sinister Or a lion rampant sinister gules armed and langued azure and azure issuant from base a mount of three of the first upon which a pasqueflower argent.
The <a href="charge%20%28heraldry%29">charge</a> on the dexter (armsbearer's right, viewer's left) side, the lion, is a reference to the village's former allegiance to the <a href="County%20of%20Veldenz">Counts of Veldenz</a> (according to one source) or the <a href="Waldgrave">Waldgrave</a>s (according to another). The charges on the sinister (armsbearer's left, viewer's right) side are a <a href="Pulsatilla">pasqueflower</a>, which within the municipality is under conservational protection at the Mittagsfels conservation area, and a three-knolled hill (a charge known in <a href="German%20heraldry">German heraldry</a> as a "Dreiberg"), representing the plant's <a href="habitat">habitat</a> (it only grows on hilly land). The arms have been borne since 1964.
Culture and sightseeing.
Buildings.

Natural monuments.
Niederalben has two nature conservation areas, Mittagsfels and Steinalbmündung, both whose names refer to the local geography. "Mittagsfels" is also a craggy formation, and the name Steinalbmündung means "mouth of the Steinalb", the local brook. Parts of the Steinalbmündung Nature Conservation Area actually also lie within <a href="Rathsweiler">Rathsweiler</a>’s and <a href="Ulmet%2C%20Germany">Ulmet’s</a> limits.
Regular events.
Niederalben holds its <a href="kermis">kermis</a> (church consecration festival, locally known as the "Kerwe") on the first Sunday in May (also called the "Maikerb"), and it still draws many former villagers who have moved elsewhere. On that Sunday, the "Straußbuben" ("bouquet lads"), and often also "Straußmädchen" ("bouquet girls"), put the "Kerwestrauß" up at the <a href="inn">inn</a>. Although it is called a "Strauß" ("bouquet"), it is actually a <a href="spruce">spruce</a> tree decorated with colourful streamers. The "Straußpfarrer" ("bouquet pastor", but not a real clergyman) then reads the rhymed "Straußpredigt" ("bouquet sermon"), which is a summary of the year's events in the village. Over the last few years, city dwellers have felt a heightened interest in this rural custom, even if the kermis is no longer celebrated like a "<a href="Poland">Polish</a> or <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n church consecration festival", as J. von Plänckner put it in 1833 in his "Beschreibung der königlich preußischen, der königlich bayerischen, der großherzoglich oldenburgischen und der landgräflich Hessen-Homburgischen Rheinlande" ("Description of the <a href="Prussia">Royal Prussian</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bavaria">Royal Bavarian</a>, <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Oldenburg">Grand Ducal Oldenburg</a> and <a href="Landgrave">Landgravial</a> <a href="Hesse-Homburg">Hesse-Homburg</a> <a href="Rhine">Rhine</a> Lands").
Clubs.
Even though the <a href="school">school</a>, the parish office and in 1996 the <a href="Deutsche%20Bundespost">post</a> as well have been withdrawn from Niederalben, and hardly any businesses can keep afloat nowadays, the villagers have still got themselves involved in clubs. Many are members of several clubs. The oldest club was the singing club, which was founded in 1890 as a men's singing club, but which has since become inactive. For a short while, there was a <a href="hiking">hiking</a> club, the "Pfälzerwaldverein", but there is no longer any interest in this. The <a href="sport%20club">sport club</a> has united with the one in <a href="Ulmet%2C%20Germany">Ulmet</a>. <a href="Association%20football">Football</a> matches were once held alternately on either Ulmet's or Niederalben's sporting ground, but since 2009, only Ulmet's has been used. Still active are a <a href="Shooting%20sport">shooting</a> club and an <a href="angling">angling</a> club. There are further an <a href="Evangelical%20Church%20in%20Germany">Evangelical</a> women's aid association and a countrywomen's club.
Economy and infrastructure.
Economic structure.
In the Steinalb valley within Niederalben's limits once stood a few <a href="Mill%20%28grinding%29">mills</a>, but in 1938 they suddenly found themselves within the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground, and have since fallen into disrepair. The only nearby mill that is still running stands near Niederalben on the Steinalb, but over on the Steinalb's right bank and thus on the far side of the old <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bavaria">Bavarian</a>-<a href="Prussia">Prussia</a>n border, within <a href="Rathsweiler">Rathsweiler</a>’s limits. Until the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, the predominant economic structure was <a href="Agriculture">agricultural</a>. Indeed, farming was about the only kind of livelihood to be had. Each farmer, though, had only a small plot and the main crops were <a href="Cereal">cereal grains</a> and <a href="potato">potato</a>es. Fruitgrowing, mainly winter <a href="apple">apple</a>s and a few <a href="vineyard">vineyard</a>s added to the agricultural mix. A major woodland in the Steinalb formed the municipal forest. Anyone who wanted a profession other than agriculture had to move to the city. After the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, this mainly meant the <a href="Ruhr%20area">Ruhr area</a>. This changed in 1938 when the <a href="Nazi%20Party">Nazis</a> established the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground. The jobs that arose there were taken even by farmers. What had been a farming village thus became a village of workers and employees. Until 1950, one <a href="Cabinetry">cabinetmaker’s</a> shop, three <a href="Shoemaking">shoemaker’s</a> shops, two <a href="tailor">tailor</a>’s shops and one <a href="Wainwright%20%28occupation%29">wainwright</a>’s shop managed to stay in business. Besides one building material wholesaler, there were still three <a href="grocery">grocery</a> shops and a <a href="butcher">butcher</a>’s shop. By 1996, only the building material wholesaler was still in business. There were, however, newer businesses by that time, a <a href="plasterwork">plasterwork</a> company and a <a href="Domestic%20roof%20construction">roofing</a> business. All other inhabitants are dependent on employment. The village has become to a great extent a residential community. Those in the workforce <a href="Commuting">commute</a> to jobs within the district and even as far as the Eastern Palatinate.
Education.
The Niederalben village <a href="school">school</a> was in existence for more than 200 years. Under the comital administration in the late 18th century, the teacher for the winter school (a school geared towards an agricultural community’s practical needs, held in the winter, when farm families had a bit more time to spare) was "rented". In 1780, a schoolteacher named Simon took on the post. It is known that in 1816, the schoolteacher earned 42 <a href="Rhenish%20guilder">Rhenish guilder</a>s yearly, which was worth 23 <a href="Reichstaler">Reichstaler</a>. The schoolteacher otherwise had to live mainly from agriculture. Even before the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, two classes were established, the small one for Jakob Klein and the big one for Peter Beuscher. Klein was a <a href="Botany">botanist</a> and set himself to the task of establishing the nature conservation area at the Mittagsfels. In 1787, for the upper and lower villages, 41 local people built a municipal centre where schoolchildren could also be taught. In 1838, between the two village centres, near the church, a schoolhouse and a teacher's dwelling were built. In 1963, a new schoolhouse was built, and the old one was torn down. In 1969, the <a href="Hauptschule">Hauptschule</a> classes were merged into the ones at the <a href="Sankt%20Julian">Sankt Julian</a> central school, as were also the <a href="primary%20school">primary school</a> classes in 1971. Since 1973, primary school pupils have been attending classes at the Ulmet/Erdesbach primary school, while the Hauptschule students have been attending the <a href="Regionale%20Schule">Regionale Schule</a> (formerly a Hauptschule) in <a href="Altenglan">Altenglan</a>. For a while, the schoolhouse in Niederalben stood empty. In 1972, it was rented by the Kusel district and then occupied by classes of a school for children with <a href="Learning%20disability">learning difficulties</a>. In 1997, this <a href="special%20school">special school</a> also left the schoolhouse in Niederalben. Since then, it has been let to the Wolfstein Christian Youth Village, but it is foreseen that the rental arrangement will soon be dissolved, whereafter the schoolhouse, dedicated in 1963, will again stand empty.
Transport.
Until the time before the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, Niederalben was linked only by a small road through the <a href="Glan%20%28Nahe%29">Glan</a> valley and a highway to <a href="Baumholder">Baumholder</a>. In 1938, on military grounds, the road now called "<a href="Bundesstra%C3%9Fe">Bundesstraße</a>" 420 was expanded by the <a href="Nazi%20Party">Nazis</a> as a link to the <a href="Siegfried%20Line">Siegfried Line</a>. It had also been on military grounds that the <a href="railway">railway</a> had been built through the Glan valley in 1903–1904. Niederalben-Rathsweiler <a href="railway%20station">railway station</a> was built in 1904 at the outlying centre of Neuwirtshaus. Originally nothing more than the Rhinegraves’ old hunting lodge, Neuwirtshaus (whose name means "new inn") became a small transport hub, for the villages up on the heights were also served from here, and once the Nazis had also set up the Baumholder Troop Drilling Ground, there were also troop movements. By the 1940s and 1950s, through traffic in the village of Niederalben had become unbearable, as troop traffic was all being driven along one narrow street through the village. In 1952, the federal government had the street expanded into a "Panzerstraße". In 1974, though, a village <a href="bypass%20%28road%29">bypass</a> was built, while the building of <a href="Autobahn">Autobahn</a> <a href="Bundesautobahn%2062">A 62</a> (<a href="Kaiserslautern">Kaiserslautern</a>–<a href="Trier">Trier</a>), running to the southwest, also greatly reduced the troop traffic running through Niederalben. In the Glan valley, "Bundesstraße" 420 (<a href="Oppenheim">Oppenheim</a>–<a href="Neunkirchen%2C%20Saarland">Neunkirchen</a>) touches the village. It also affords a link from Niederalben to the district seat of <a href="Kusel">Kusel</a> and to the lower <a href="Nahe%20%28Rhine%29">Nahe</a> area (<a href="Bad%20Kreuznach">Bad Kreuznach</a>). The railway line was abandoned about 1985. Serving <a href="Altenglan">Altenglan</a> is <a href="Altenglan%20station">Altenglan station</a>, which is on the <a href="Landstuhl%E2%80%93Kusel%20railway">Landstuhl–Kusel railway</a> and is served hourly by <a href="Regionalbahn">Regionalbahn</a> service RB 67 to and from <a href="Kaiserslautern%20Central%20Station">Kaiserslautern</a>, called the "Glantalbahn" (the name of which refers to the <a href="Glan%20Valley%20Railway">Glan Valley Railway</a>, which shared some of the route of the Landstuhl–Kusel line, including the former railway junction at Altenglan).
